Title: Does $\sqrt{a+b} \le \sqrt a + \sqrt b$ hold for all positive real numbers $a$ and $b$?
Content: I thought of this a while ago, but can't make up a proof or a counterexample. Does anyone know more about this? $$\sqrt{a+b}  \le \sqrt a + \sqrt b , \forall a,b \in \mathbb R_+$$ Moreover, what happens with more variables? Say: $$\sqrt{x_1+x_2+...+x_n} \le \sqrt {x_1} +\sqrt {x_2} + ... + \sqrt {x_n} $$ with $ x_i \in\mathbb R_+, \forall i \in \{1,2,...,n\}$ or when $i = \mathbb N$ . PS: I tried looking on the internet for this but I don't know how I would call this.
